This
On
Week
List
Fiction
BLACK NOTICE, by Patricia Cornwell. (Berkley, $7.99.) Dr. Kay Scarpetta's investigation of a ship's cargo involves her in an international conspiracy.
THE ALIBI, by Sandra Brown. (Warner, $7.99.) Jealousy, intrigue and corruption beset a Charleston lawyer during his pursuit of public office.
HEARTS IN ATLANTIS, by Stephen King. (Pocket Books, $7.99.) Five long, interconnected stories about an America haunted by the Vietnam War.
TARA ROAD, by Maeve Binchy. (Dell, $7.99.) Two women -- one from Ireland, one from New England -- learn a lot about each other and themselves when they exchange houses for the summer.
THE POISONWOOD BIBLE, by Barbara Kingsolver. (Perennial/HarperCollins, $14.) Five female characters narrate a novel set in the Belgian Congo during that country's fight for independence.
TEARS OF THE MOON, by Nora Roberts. (Jove, $7.99.) An Irish songwriter, shut off from the world, finds hope and happiness with a tomboy.
THE GUEST LIST, by Fern Michaels. (Zebra, $7.50.) Two sisters who have been reunited after years apart give a magnificent party, but an uninvited guest threatens their newfound happiness.
WHILE I WAS GONE, by Sue Miller. (Ballantine, $12.95.) A small-town veterinarian, the wife of a minister, begins a flirtation with an old friend from her bohemian past.
ASHES TO ASHES, by Tami Hoag. (Bantam, $7.99.) Kate Conlan, a former F.B.I. agent, tracks a serial killer, known as the Cremator, in Minneapolis.
DARK LADY, by Richard North Patterson. (Ballantine, $7.99.) Stella Marz, a driven county prosecutor, pursues criminals infesting a struggling Midwestern city.
HANNIBAL, by Thomas Harris. (Dell, $7.99.) Seven years after his escape, the fiendish psychiatrist Hannibal Lecter is still at large.
AGENTS OF CHAOS: Hero's Trial, by James Luceno. (Lucas/Del Rey/Ballantine, $6.99.) A new novel in the series ''Star Wars: The New Jedi Order.''
THE SAVING GRACES, by Patricia Gaffney. (HarperTorch, $6.99.) The close friendship that binds four women is put to the test.
GRANNY DAN, by Danielle Steel. (Dell, $7.50.) A woman learns the secrets of her grandmother's past in czarist Russia.
BLUE GOLD, by Clive Cussler with Paul Kemprecos. (Pocket Books, $16.) Kurt Austin tries to thwart a California tycoon's plan to control the world's freshwater supply.

This
On
Week
List
Nonfiction
THE PERFECT STORM, by Sebastian Junger. (Perennial/HarperCollins, $14; HarperPaperbacks, $6.99.) The story of the northeaster of 1991, focusing on a crew of fishermen from Gloucester, Mass.
THE SEAT OF THE SOUL, by Gary Zukav. (Fireside/Simon & Schuster, $12.) How daily activities can be enhanced by feelings of meaning and purpose. (+)
THE HUNGRY OCEAN, by Linda Greenlaw. (Hyperion, $14.) A sea captain's account of her 30-day swordfishing voyage off the Northeast coast.
GIRL, INTERRUPTED, by Susanna Kaysen. (Vintage, $12.) A memoir of a young woman's mental illness.
A CHILD CALLED ''IT,'' by Dave Pelzer. (Health Communications, $9.95.) The autobiography of a man who survived his mother's abuse. (+)
A WALK IN THE WOODS, by Bill Bryson. (Broadway, $13.) A journalist finds beauty and humor while hiking the Appalachian Trail.

*ISAAC'S STORM, by Erik Larson. (Vintage, $13.) An account of America's deadliest hurricane, which killed 6,000 people in Galveston, Tex., in 1900, and the Weather Bureau scientist who failed to forecast it.
THE ELEGANT UNIVERSE, by Brian Greene. (Vintage, $15.) A physicist's presentation of superstring theory, which attempts to mediate between quantum mechanics and general relativity.
I'M A STRANGER HERE MYSELF, by Bill Bryson. (Broadway, $14.) The author describes what it's like to return to the United States after living abroad for two decades.
THE LOST BOY, by Dave Pelzer. (Health Communications, $10.95.) The author of ''A Child Called 'It' ''recalls his life at a series of foster homes. (+)
THE LEXUS AND THE OLIVE TREE, by Thomas L. Friedman. (Anchor, $15.) A journalist explains the instant electronic global economy.
*ANGELA'S ASHES, by Frank McCourt. (Touchstone/Simon & Schuster, $14 and $7.99.) An Irish-American writer recalls his childhood amid the miseries of Limerick.
THE PROFESSOR AND THE MADMAN, by Simon Winchester. (Perennial/HarperCollins, $13.) How a murderer and certified lunatic helped James Murray compile the Oxford English Dictionary.
INTO THIN AIR, by Jon Krakauer. (Anchor, $13 and $7.99.) Ascending Mount Everest in 1996, the deadliest season in history.
GUNS, GERMS, AND STEEL, by Jared Diamond. (Norton, $14.95.) A physiologist attributes Western dominance to geographical advantages. (+)

Advice, How-to and Miscellaneous: Hardcover
WHO MOVED MY CHEESE? by Spencer Johnson. (Putnam, $19.95.) How to deal with changes at work and in life in general. (+)
BODY FOR LIFE, by Bill Phillips with Michael D'Orso. (HarperCollins, $26.) Ways to improve one's body and one's life. (+)
TEN THINGS I WISH I'D KNOWN -- before i went out into the real world, by Maria Shriver. (Warner, $19.95.) Life lessons. (+)
RELATIONSHIP RESCUE, by Phillip C. McGraw. (Hyperion, $22.95.) A seven-step program for reconnecting with one's partner. (+)
SIMPLE ABUNDANCE, by Sarah Ban Breathnach. (Warner, $21.) Advice for women seeking to improve the way they look at themselves. (+)

Advice, How-to and Miscellaneous: Paperback
RICH DAD, POOR DAD, by Robert T. Kiyosaki with Sharon L. Lechter. (Warner, $15.95.) Teaching one's children how to get rich and stay rich.
TAKE TIME FOR YOUR LIFE, by Cheryl Richardson. (Broadway, $13.) A seven-step program for enhancing social, financial and spiritual well-being. (+)
DR. ATKINS' NEW DIET REVOLUTION, by Robert C. Atkins. (Avon, $14 and $6.99.) Ways to lose weight and achieve a healthy body. (+)
THE FOUR AGREEMENTS, by Don Miguel Ruiz. (Amber-Allen, $12.95.) A code of conduct based on personal freedom. (+)
THE OTHER SIDE AND BACK, by Sylvia Browne with Lindsay Harrison. (Signet, $7.50.) A psychic's guide to coping with the world and the future. (+)

Rankings reflect sales, for the week ending Aug. 5, at almost 4,000 bookstores plus wholesalers serving 60,000 other retailers (gift shops, department stores, newsstands, supermarkets), statistically weighted to represent all such outlets nationwide. An asterisk (*) indicates that a book's sales are barely distinguishable from those of the book above. A dagger (+)indicates that some bookstores report receiving bulk orders. Expanded rankings are available at The New York Times on the Web: www.nytimes.com/books.
